title: UK weather forecast: Typhoon Hagibis 'to trigger washouts and gales in Britain'
text:

Killer Typhoon Hagibis is set to cause days of washouts and 50mph gales to Britain as the tempest on the other side of the world strengthens Atlantic storms.

Forecasters said Hagibis, Japan's worst typhoon for 60 years, is set to impact weather 10,000 miles away in Scotland by making the rain and wind even worse, creating new flood fears.

Hagibis' effects are expected in the second half of the week, said forecaster John Hammond of weathertrending, after the Met Office issued a rain warning for much of England.

Dramatic weather maps show high-altitude Atlantic jet stream winds steering stormy low-pressure systems to Scotland, with more than two inches of rain expected for many this week.

(Image: Met Office)

The Met Office is predicting showers on Monday and a drier day on Tuesday before "intense" rain bursts and gale-force gusts up to 50mph from Wednesday, with rain and wind lasting into the weekend.

Forecaster Michael Fish, of Netweather, said: "It's rain, rain and yet more rain."

Met Office forecaster Marco Petagna added: "Some of Typhoon Hagibis' energy might well get caught up in North Atlantic weather and could develop low pressure areas close to the UK."

Hagibis killed at least 24 people in Japan as it tore apart homes, caused widespread flooding by dumping almost 40ins of rain in just 24 hours, and triggered landslides.

(Image: REUTERS)

Met Office Science tweeted: "By affecting the jet stream, Hagibis could influence UK weather in the next week.

"Hagibis' warm air contrasting with a cold front will accelerate the jet stream by 100mph.

"Disturbances on the other side of the world can influence UK weather."

Mr Hammond said: "Hagibis may well have a knock-on effect on our weather.

"The upshot may be rain-bearing fronts lodged across the UK as we end the week.

(Image: PA)

"Hagibis' remnants are tearing across the north Pacific in the direction of Alaska, punching into high northern latitudes.

"This may cause larger jet stream peaks and troughs downstream, stalling the progress of weather systems across Britain."

There are fresh fears of flooding given this week's forecast.

Met Office forecaster Grahame Madge said: "After recent rain, there is the risk of flooding from further rain.

"A brief drier interlude on Tuesday is followed by Wednesday and Thursday seeing intense showers in the West, with 50mph gusts possible locally from Wednesday to Friday on coasts.

"More low pressure is forecast on Friday and the unsettled pattern expected to continue into the weekend."

The Met Office has issued a severe weather warning with more than two inches of rain expected to fall in just 12 hours on Monday from 12pm.

The yellow warning covers much of England - including London, Birmingham and Manchester - extending from the southern coast of Devon up to Yorkshire.

(Image: REUTERS)

The Met Office said: "Rain is expected to move northwards across much of England on Monday, heavy at times, especially during the afternoon and evening.

"15 to 25mm is likely to fall quite widely, and there is potential for 40 to 60mm to fall in a few places.

"This brings a risk of flooding and disruption, but the situation is uncertain such that the likelihood of this across any given county is small.

"The rain is expected to clear away northeastwards during Monday evening and night."

The Environment Agency had already issued one flood warning and 31 flood alerts following days of downpours.

(Image: The Asahi Shimbun via Getty Imag)

The warning covered Winford Brook at Chew Magna, south of Bristol.

It appears wet and windy weather will dominate through the rest of October and into November with only short-lived spells of dry conditions.

Ireland's Met Éireann has issued status yellow warnings for most of the country ahead of heavy rain on Sunday evening and all of Monday.

Met Office five-day weather forecast

Sunday

Rain, some heavy, moving north across England, Wales and southern Scotland, followed by sunny spells and isolated showers in the south.

Elsewhere, fog patches clearing, then sunny spells and showers, some heavy in the west.

Windy in south and east.

Sunday night

Rain in the north-east clearing, then clear spells and lighter winds, so some frost and fog in central and northern areas.

Further rain in the far south by morning.

Monday

Fog patches in the north clearing, then mostly dry with sunny spells.

Rain affecting southern and central areas, as well as Northern Ireland, after a dry and bright start.

Tuesday to Thursday

Largely dry Tuesday, following eastward clearance of early rain; any fog or low cloud steadily breaking up into sunny spells.

Further wind and rain Wednesday, followed by scattered showers Thursday.
description: The Met Office says Typhoon Hagibis - which has killed at least 24 people in Japan - threatens to impact weather 10,000 miles away in Britain by making the rain and wind even worse
